title: Charles Mallam
text:
Charles George Cave Mallam (4 August 1859 – 8 December 1950) was an <a href="English%20people">English</a> first-class <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er and educator.
The son of Thomas Mallam, he was born in August 1859 at Iffley Manor House in <a href="Iffley">Iffley, Oxfordshire</a>. He was educated at <a href="Uppingham%20School">Uppingham School</a>, before matriculating at the <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">University of Oxford</a> in October 1878 as a non-collegiate student. While studying at Oxford, he made a single appearance in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for <a href="Oxford%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Oxford University</a> against the <a href="Gentlemen%20of%20England">Gentlemen of England</a> at <a href="University_Parks%23Cricket_ground">Oxford</a> in 1882. Batting twice in the match, he was dismissed for 2 runs in the Oxford first innings by <a href="A.%20P.%20Lucas">Bunny Lucas</a>, while in their second innings he was <a href="not%20out">unbeaten</a> on 2 runs. With his right-arm <a href="Spin%20bowling">slow bowling</a>, he bowled a total of 21 <a href="over%20%28cricket%29">overs</a> across both Gentlemen of England innings' without taking a wicket.
Mallam played his <a href="county%20cricket">county cricket</a> for Devon and Rutland, appearing for both in minor matches. Beside playing cricket, Mallam also played <a href="association%20football">football</a> for <a href="Uppingham%20Rovers%20F.%20C.">Uppingham Rovers F. C.</a> from 1882–86. He was by profession a teacher and was the headmaster of <a href="Dunchurch-Winton%20Hall">Dunchurch Hall Preparatory School</a>. Mallam died at <a href="Brentwood%2C%20Essex">Brentwood</a> in December 1950.
